channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Giorgia Meloni Wins Voting in Italy, in Breakthrough for Europe’s Hard Right
item.description: Her nationalist party was the top vote-getter, leaving Ms. Meloni poised to be Italy’s first female prime minister and the first with post-Fascist roots.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni at a press conference she gave after early projections had her coalition winning a majority in Parliament, in Rome early Monday.

item.title: A third of Italians sat out the election, a steep drop from 2018.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station worker preparing a ballot at a high school in Rome on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Begins Mobilizing Ukrainians to Fight Against Their Own Country
item.description: Panic and fear flooded the occupied territories as Russian forces rounded up men to fight and forced residents to vote in a staged referendum on joining Russia, Ukrainian officials and rights groups said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: A polling station in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Saturday, the second day of a referendum on joining the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic to Russia.

item.title: U.S. Warns Russia of ‘Catastrophic Consequences’ if It Uses Nuclear Weapons
item.description: The comments by the national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, illustrate how quickly the rhetoric has intensified as Russia has faltered on the battlefield in recent months.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, this month. American intelligence officials say they still believe the chances that nuclear weapons will be used in the conflict are low.

item.title: The Megastate G.O.P. Rivalry Between Abbott and DeSantis
item.description: Publicly, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas has not criticized the migrant flights from his state by Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. Privately, the Florida governor’s stunt stung the Texas governor’s team.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender and J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Office of the Texas Governor
item.media:description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, left, and Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas in 2021 in Del Rio, Texas.

item.title: Renovated C.I.A. and N.S.A. Museums Offer a Peek at Spy Secrets — for Some
item.description: The Central Intelligence Agency and the National Security Agency both recently overhauled their showcases of espionage.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: A pigeon wearing a spy camera is on display at the recently renovated museum at C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va.

item.title: Sundance Liked Her Documentary, ‘Jihad Rehab,’ Until Muslim Critics Didn’t
item.description: The film festival gave Meg Smaker’s “Jihad Rehab” a coveted spot in its 2022 lineup, but apologized after an outcry over her race and her approach.
item.dc:creator: Michael Powell
item.media:credit: Tai Power Seeff for The New York Times
item.media:description: After criticism by Arab American and Muslim filmmakers led to the film being shunned by festivals, Meg Smaker renamed her documentary “The UnRedacted.”

item.title: Iran Protests Are Fueled in Part by Kurdish Anger
item.description: The protests that have swept Iran following the death of a woman in police custody have been especially intense in the country’s minority Kurdish population.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Safin Hamed/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters in Erbil, the capital of Iraq’s semiautonomous Kurdistan Region, burning an Iranian flag on Saturday.

item.title: Whatever Happened to the Starter Home?
item.description: The economics of the housing market, and the local rules that shape it, have squeezed out entry-level homes.

item.title: This Surveillance Artist Knows How You Got That Perfect Instagram Photo
item.description: A tech-savvy artist unearthed video footage of people working hard to capture the perfect shot for Instagram. It is a lesson in the artifice of social media and the ubiquity of surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill

item.title: What We Learned From Week 3 in the N.F.L.
item.description: In a battle of headliner quarterbacks, Tom Brady vs. Aaron Rodgers needed more co-stars; Trevor Lawrence and the Jaguars look legit; and the Bills could’ve used some help with the Dolphins’ receivers.
item.dc:creator: Derrik Klassen
item.media:credit: Julio Aguilar/Getty Images
item.media:description: Aaron Rodgers completed passes to eight different Packers teammates, including two for touchdowns, in Sunday’s 14-12 win over Tom Brady and the Buccaneers.

item.title: Black NFL Players Still Wear Their Hair in Locs Despite the Challenges
item.description: N.F.L. players who wear dreadlocks risk being tackled by their hair and face helmet-fitting challenges. But they say expressing their identities and showing off their style is worth it.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Fred Kfoury III/Icon Sportswire via Getty Images
item.media:description: About 18 percent of players on active N.F.L. rosters — or nearly one in five players on every club — wear their hair dreadlocked or braided, according to an informal tally compiled from roster headshots from all 32 teams.

item.title: The Essential Judy Blume
item.description: For 50 years, her books have educated, entertained and connected young readers. Whether you want to revisit a classic or inspire a new fan, here’s what to read.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.category: Starring Sally J. Freedman as Herself (Book)
Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing (Book)
Otherwise Known as Sheila the Great (Book)
Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret (Book)
item.media:credit: Evening Standard/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images

item.title: Beto O’Rourke on Abbott’s Dehumanizing Stunts and Why He Hopes an Upset Looms in Texas
item.description: In an interview, he told me about how he views his campaign to unseat the Republican governor of Texas.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Eric Gay/Associated Press

item.title: In Washington State, the Midterm Race Between Joe Kent and Marie Gluesenkamp Perez Has It All
item.description: This congressional race in Washington State shows the November elections in microcosm.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times

item.title: This Threat to Democracy Is Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: Trump and his allies are trying to take over the machinery of American elections.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; photograph by Stephen Maturen, via Getty Images

item.title: Do Not Bring Your ‘Whole Self’ to Work
item.description: Beware the latest fad from Human Resources.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul

item.title: My Parents Are Hackers Out of Necessity
item.description: Both skateboarding and navigating daily life with a disability involve surprisingly similar ways of engaging with the built environment.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Klemin

item.title: What Putin’s Nuclear Threat Means for Ukraine and the U.S.
item.description: Russia is flailing and losing. The nuclear threat is growing.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Putin and Trump, the Solo Soulless Saboteurs
item.description: Putin and Trump, dragging the world down with them.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yury Kochetkov

item.title: Why Religious Freedom Matters, Even if You’re Not Religious
item.description: “If speech is popular, it doesn’t really need constitutional protection,” David French says.
item.dc:creator: Tish Harrison Warren
item.media:credit: Matija Medved

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Quest by Circadian Medicine to Make the Most of Our Body Clocks’
item.description: Researchers are trying to figure out the right hour of the day to do everything. Can their studies sync us up with better health?
item.dc:creator: Kim Tingley, Jack D’Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Marion Lozano and Quinton Kamara
item.media:credit: Concept by Pablo Delcan. Photo Illustration by Bobby Doherty for The New York Times.

item.title: Modern Love Podcast: How to Feel Yourself
item.description: At 83, and legally blind, a woman needs help with one of her favorite pastimes: visiting the sex shop.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: After Dobbs: Feminism Beyond the Gender Binary
item.description: Jennifer Finney Boylan and Thomas Page McBee on what the feminist movement owes the trans community.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Angela Weiss/Agence France-Presses via Getty Images

item.title: You Need Only 7 Ingredients
item.description: Make the most out of very little.
item.dc:creator: Emily Weinstein
item.media:credit: Ryan Liebe for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.

item.title: Dodging Blackouts, California Faces New Questions on Its Power Supply
item.description: Extreme heat is testing the way energy is generated, delivered and traded — and raising the prospect of perpetual emergencies.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Power lines in Cathedral City, Calif. During a heat wave this month, the operator of California’s electric grid faced the highest demand the system had ever seen.

item.title: Welfare Scandal in Mississippi May Tarnish Brett Favre’s Legacy
item.description: His role in the misappropriation of welfare money has infuriated people in his native Mississippi and prompted some fans to call for his removal from the Hall of Fame.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:credit: Shelley Mays/USA TODAY NETWORK

item.title: Former Texas Police Officer Acquitted in 2020 Shooting Death of Black Man
item.description: Officer Shaun Lucas, who is white, shot 31-year-old Jonathan Price four times. After the encounter, he was fired.
item.dc:creator: Neelam Bohra
item.media:credit: Montinique Monroe/Getty Images
item.media:description: A memorial for Jonathan Price outside the gas station where he was killed in Wolfe City, Texas, in 2020.

item.title: Silicon Valley Slides Back Into ‘Bro’ Culture
item.description: Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg and Marc Andreessen show how the tech industry’s insular culture remains largely unchanged.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Cari Vander Yacht

item.title: Is Natural Wine Actually Better for You?
item.description: Fewer headaches. Less severe hangovers. Better gut health. How do these health claims stack up against the science?
item.dc:creator: Jesse Hirsch
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: When Should I Get the New Bivalent Booster?
item.description: You are allowed to get the shot two months after a previous dose, but some experts suggest waiting a little longer.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times

item.title: How to Exercise Safely Outside in the Fall and Winter
item.description: Here are a few ways to protect yourself from the elements, oncoming traffic and other threats that ramp up in the fall and winter months.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasús

item.title: ‘Preventative’ Botox: Do Injections Work to Reduce Wrinkles?
item.description: Or are injections just a temporary, addictive fix?
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About Fentanyl and Why It’s So Dangerous
item.description: Drug overdoses have reached record highs. Experts offer tips to talk about opioids with your family.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Nicolas Ortega, Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: An Italian Villa Where Architecture Is a Family Affair
item.description: Most homes hold the history of their owners, but Il Palazzetto is as much a monument to its designers as to its inhabitants.
item.dc:creator: Max Norman and Danilo Scarpati

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
